briefings.headline: Samsung Says Rising Memory Costs May Drive Up Consumer Product Prices
briefings.dek: World’s largest memory maker says it may need to pass component cost burden to consumers as prices surge industrywide.
briefings.body:
Samsung Electronics expects memory chip supply shortages to drive up prices across the electronics industry, including potentially for its own consumer products, according to the company’s head of global marketing, Wonjin Lee.

Lee said in an interview with Bloomberg that memory prices are rising “even as we speak.” “There’s going to be issues around semiconductor supplies, and it’s going to affect everyone,” Lee said. “Obviously, we don’t want to convey that burden to the consumers, but we’re going to be at a point where we have to actually consider repricing our products.”

The AI data center buildout boom has created unprecedented demand for high-bandwidth memory, constraining supply for smartphones, laptops, and other consumer devices.

Lee said the company is optimistic about 2026, particularly for AI-enabled mobile phones, and expects Samsung to outpace the broader market despite industrywide supply pressures.

briefings.headline: Nvidia CEO Says Chinese Demand for H200 Chips “Quite High”
briefings.dek: Jensen Huang said demand levels will be the “most conclusive sign” of Beijing’s views on advanced AI processors
briefings.body:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said on Tuesday that Chinese demand for the company’s H200 AI chips is “quite high” and that purchase orders from local tech firms will be the clearest signal of Beijing’s approval, The Wall Street Journal reported.

At the Consumer Electronics Show, Huang told reporters that Nvidia has already asked its supply chain to ramp up production for H200, citing high demand. Huang added that he doesn’t anticipate problems from the Chinese side once U.S. officials complete licensing reviews.

“We learn about everything through purchase orders. We’re not expecting any press releases or any large declarations,” Huang said, “It’s just going to be purchase orders. If the purchase orders come, it’s because they’re able to place purchase orders.”

President Donald Trump said last month he planned to approve export licenses for the H200, the predecessor to Nvidia’s flagship Blackwell chips, in a deal that includes giving the federal government a 25% cut of sales. H200 was never allowed to sell to China under U.S. chip export controls that took effect in 2022.

related_items.title: China Weighs Nvidia Chip Purchase in Emergency Meetings With Tech Companies

briefings.headline: China Reviews Meta’s $2 Billion acquisition of Manus
briefings.dek: Manus founders moved to Singapore last year to de-emphasize its Chinese roots.
briefings.body:
The Chinese government is reviewing Meta Platforms’ $2 billion acquisition of AI startup Manus for potential violations of technology export control, the Financial Times reported on Wednesday, citing two people familiar with the matter.

China’s Ministry of Commerce has begun assessing whether the relocation of Manus’s staff and technology to Singapore from China, and the subsequent sale to Meta,  required an export license under Chinese law, the FT reported.

Manus, a general-purpose agentic AI application, was started in China and went viral with global users in the spring of last year. Butterfly Effect, the startup behind Manus, received funding from Benchmark in April last year and later set up new headquarters in Singapore, where its founders also live now. The move was to ensure that the startup can continue to do business in the U.S. and not be constrained by its Chinese roots, The Information reported previously.

related_items.title: Startup Behind Manus AI Agent Navigates U.S.-China Tensions After Benchmark Deal

briefings.headline: Ilya Sutskever Had $4 Billion of Vested OpenAI Equity in 2023
briefings.dek: The value of Sutskever’s financial stake has been a point of contention in Musk’s lawsuit.
briefings.body:
OpenAI co-founder and former chief scientist Ilya Sutskever had $4 billion worth of vested equity in OpenAI in November 2023, according to text messages from chief operating officer Brad Lightcap that were made public Tuesday as part of Elon Musk’s lawsuit against OpenAI.

Lightcap disclosed Sutskever’s financial stake after the OpenAI board fired CEO Sam Altman and Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella prepared to hire Altman and OpenAI colleagues. Lightcap wrote to Altman and Nadella that paying OpenAI employees for their equity would require $25 billion excluding Sutskever’s equity, or $29 billion including Sutskever’s vested units. (It’s not clear how much Sutskever had in unvested equity.)

The day following the exchange, Microsoft chief technology officer Kevin Scott said publicly that Microsoft would hire and match the compensation of every OpenAI employee who chose to resign from the startup, in the event that Altman was not reinstated at OpenAI. Those hires never happened because the OpenAI board rehired Altman later that night.

Sutskever’s $4 billion stock compensation shows that AI labs have been willing to provide lavish pay for top AI researchers even before last year’s intense war for talent. In 2023, OpenAI was valued at $29 billion and in the process of a tender offer that would value it at $86 billion. Altman has said he does not own equity in OpenAI.

The value of Sutskever’s financial stake in OpenAI has been a matter of contention in the lawsuit. Sutskever refused to reveal the details during a deposition in October, but the court ordered him to sit for a second deposition because the judge found that “Sutskever’s financial interest in OpenAI is directly relevant” to whether his testimony is biased in favor of OpenAI, among other reasons.

briefings.headline: Musk Pushed OpenAI to Link With Microsoft, Called Amazon’s Bezos a ‘Tool’
briefings.dek: Google Co-Founder Sergey Brin Sought to Hire Greg Brockman, Nadella said.
briefings.body:
Elon Musk in 2016 told fellow OpenAI founder Sam Altman that the AI lab, then one year old, should pursue a cloud computing deal with Microsoft rather than Amazon, according to emails released Tuesday as evidence in Elon Musk’s federal lawsuit against OpenAI.

Musk explained that he preferred Microsoft’s CEO Satya Nadella over Amazon’s CEO, who was then founder Jeff Bezos. “I think Jeff is a bit of a tool and Satya is not, so I slightly prefer Microsoft, but I hate their marketing dept.” Altman replied that “Amazon started really dicking us around on the [terms and conditions], especially on marketing commits. And their offering wasn’t that good technically anyway.”

Microsoft three years later invested $1 billion in the startup, which it later increased to $13 billion, forging a landmark partnership in which Microsoft gets a share of OpenAI’s revenue until 2030 or until the startup develops human-level AI. Amazon made an early bet on Anthropic, though it’s been in talks to invest $10 billion in OpenAI, which would use Amazon’s AI chips.

Nadella recounted in his own deposition how rivals quickly moved to recruit OpenAI’s leaders after the board fired Altman in late 2023. Google co-founder Sergey Brin “reached out to” OpenAI president Greg Brockman, Nadella said, according to the transcript of the September deposition, which was also made public Tuesday.

One of Nadella’s goals at the time was “to make sure that Sam and Greg were not just standing up an alternative lab,” he said. But “some of them were getting calls from everybody else, from Sundar [Pichai] and Mark [Zuckerberg] and even Elon [Musk] in some cases.”

In a text message that a lawyer read aloud at the meeting, former OpenAI chief technology officer Mira Murati wrote following Altman’s termination that “Satya said he’s helping with calming down Sam so he doesn’t do anything hypercompetitive,” such as starting a new AI company. Nadella, two days after Altman’s termination, said he had offered jobs to Altman and Brockman.

briefings.headline: MSCI Decides to Keep Crypto-Holding Stocks in Indexes
briefings.dek: Shares of Strategy, a bitcoin-holding stock, jumped after the index provider’s decision.
briefings.body:
MSCI, a major index provider, said Tuesday that it decided to keep publicly-traded stocks whose primary activities are buying crypto in its global indexes “at this time.” The decision removes for now a potential threat to battered companies like Strategy.

The decision was highly watched because a potential exclusion of the stocks from MSCI indexes could force index-tracking funds to sell their shares, putting further downward pressure on crypto prices.

Strategy, the biggest bitcoin holding stock, jumped 6.7% in post-market trading after MSCI’s decision. MSCI said it “intends to open a broader consultation” on these stocks, and that feedback so far confirmed that some institutional investors are concerned the stocks are similar to investment funds, which are not eligible for inclusion in the indexes.

briefings.headline: Former VP Sues Insight Partners for Gender Discrimination
briefings.dek: Insight denies the allegations.
briefings.body:
Katherine Lowry, who joined Insight Partners as a vice president in 2022, has filed a lawsuit in a California state court accusing her former employer of wrongful termination and gender discrimination.

Lowry says her compensation was cut after taking medical leave from $750,000 to $500,000 in expected carried interest and alleges that her manager, a female executive, “berated” her and told her that “your work needs to be twice as good as male colleagues because you are a woman.”

Insight said in a statement that the allegations are “baseless” and the complaint “paints a false picture of our workplace and employment practices and does not reflect the culture, values, or conduct of our organization.”

Bloomberg first reported the news.

briefings.headline: XAI Raises $20 Billion From Valor, Nvidia
briefings.dek: Musk's AI lab said it had originally set out to raise $15 billion.
briefings.body:
XAI, Elon Musk’s AI lab, said Tuesday it had raised $20 billion from investors including Valor Equity Partners, Stepstone Group, and Fidelity, as well as Nvidia and Cisco. That’s more money than the initial $15 billion the company had targeted, at a $230 billion valuation. At that level, the financing would more than double the last valuation of the AI business, which combined with X (formerly Twitter) last year.

The round,  the two-year-old company’s Series E, will help the company with ambitious goals to expand the comput clusters powering its AI models. XAI recently bought a building for a third supersized data center it’s planning outside Memphis, Tennessee, The Information reported last week. XAI said it has amassed chips with the computing capacity of 1 million Nvidia H100s.

briefings.headline: AI Lab Hark Hires Leadership from Apple, Meta
briefings.dek: The startup aims to develop its own AI devices.
briefings.body:
Hark, the AI lab that Figure AI CEO Brett Adcock recently founded, has hired over 30 engineers, including Head of Design Abidur Chowdhury, who previously designed phones and laptops for Apple, according to a copy of a memo Adcock sent to senior Figure employees and investors on Tuesday seen by The Information.

Chowdhury’s hire is a sign that Hark plans to differentiate itself from other AI labs by focusing on AI devices. “My view is simple: today’s AI models aren’t nearly intelligent enough, they feel quite dumb, and the devices we use to access them are fundamentally pre-AI,” Adcock wrote. “Our computers and phones are reactive - they sit idle, waiting for instructions - rather than proactive systems that truly work alongside us.”

Hark also hired former Apple employees David Narajowski and Dave Wilkes to work on hardware, along with Eddie Lou, who previously worked on Meta glasses. Key AI hires also hail from Meta, including Mingbo Ma, Xubo Liu, Xianfeng Rui, Kainan Peng, Zhihong Lei and Pengwei Li.

Hark has also hired engineers from Google and Amazon, according to the memo, and the startup could grow to 100 engineers during the first half of the year.

Adcock is funding Hark with $100 million of his personal capital. Adcock said in his memo that he’s “already using the models daily” that the company has worked on since last month, and he expects its first public model to release this summer.

briefings.headline: Amazon’s “Buy For Me” Feature Sparks Backlash From Small Retailers
briefings.dek: Some retailers objected to their products being sold on Amazon through the feature without their permission first.
briefings.body:
Amazon has sparked blowback from some small retailers over a feature that displays items not sold on its site in Amazon search results, with some business owners objecting to Amazon not seeking permission before listing their products.

Amazon launched the feature, called “Shop Other Stores Directly,” in April, but has been ramping up how many products are listed through the feature recently. When shoppers search for branded items on Amazon’s site, Amazon will show shoppers items sold on its own site, as well as products only available on outside sites. Some of the product listings include a “Buy For Me” button shoppers can use to buy from other sites without leaving Amazon. In recent days, in viral videos and social media posts, some retailers objected to their products being sold on Amazon through the feature, saying it was confusing for shoppers and sometimes resulted in erroneous orders.

An Amazon spokesperson said that businesses can opt out of the feature at any time and that items will be removed promptly. “Shop Direct and Buy for Me are programs we’re testing that help customers discover brands and products not currently sold in Amazon’s store, while helping businesses reach new customers and drive incremental sales,” the spokesperson said.

briefings.headline: Nvidia Unveils Rubin and Announces New Open Source Autonomous Driving Model
briefings.dek: Nvidia is making its new self-driving models open source, which could ultimately drive sales of more Nvidia chips.
briefings.body:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang on Monday announced a new autonomous driving model that aims to help cars reach Level 4 autonomous driving, in which a driver isn’t required to supervise the vehicle.

Separately, Huang also announced more detailed specifications for the company’s upcoming next-generation flagship AI chips, known as Rubin. The family of chips are designed to reduce the cost of generating AI tokens by as much as tenfold, when compared with its previous generation chips, the company said.

They also aim to cut the number of GPUs needed to train mixture-of-experts models by a factor of four. Those models use far less computing power by sending each query only to the most relevant parts of the model, rather than activating the entire model at once.

Speaking in a keynote presentation at the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Huang said Nvidia’s new family of self-driving models called Alpamayo are the world’s first that can think and reason. “We imagine that someday a billion cars on a road will all be autonomous,” he said.

Nvidia is making its Alpamayo models open source, which allows outside developers to build their own self-driving cars based on its tech. That could ultimately drive sales of more Nvidia chips.

Huang said the first cars based on Nvidia’s self-driving tech would be made by Mercedes-Benz and be on the road by the first quarter of this year in the U.S. Those cars, however, will only offer Level 2 autonomous driving, which requires drivers to still supervise the vehicle.

briefings.headline: Venezuela-focused Stablecoin Startup To Make Hacked Customers Whole
briefings.dek: Last week The Information reported that JPMorgan in November froze the accounts of Kontigo .
briefings.body:
Venezuela-focused stablecoin startup Kontigo said it will repay the $340,000 that was stolen from more than 1,000 of its customers in a hack, according to a statement the company issued on Monday.

In a statement published to X, Kontigo said it detected unauthorized access that affected some users’ funds and that it would refund the full amount of stolen funds. The company estimated at least $340,000 had been stolen so far, but said it would post further updates on the situation. Last week, several Kontigo customers posted screenshots to X of notifications from the company of unauthorized attempts to access their accounts. “We immediately isolated the systems involved, activated our security protocols, and are conducting an active investigation to determine the extent of the incident,” the company said. Kontigo’s CEO Jesus Castillo did not respond immediately to a request for comment.

Last week The Information reported that JPMorgan in November froze the accounts of Kontigo after seeing a high rate of disputed transactions. Kontigo is backed by venture fund Y Combinator and offered customers the ability to open virtual accounts with the bank through an intermediary fintech, Checkbook.

briefings.headline: Polymarket Launches Bets on Housing Prices
briefings.dek: The prediction market is diversifying the types of bets it offers.
briefings.body:
Polymarket said Monday that it is launching prediction markets on U.S. housing prices, using data from Parcl, a real estate data and trading platform.

Users can bet, for example, on the median home value in San Francisco on a given date. The outcome will be based on Parcl’s data. Parcl, backed by crypto venture firms including Archetype and Dragonfly, allows people to bet on housing prices without owning physical properties.

Prediction markets are trying to diversify the categories of bets they offer.  On Polymarket, sports betting currently makes up about half of its trading volume, followed by bets related to crypto prices. “Real estate should be a first-class category in prediction markets,” said Polymarket’s chief marketing officer Matthew Modabber in a release.

Kalshi also offers real estate-related bets, such as rent increases in San Francisco and New York, based on data from Zillow and StreetEasy.

briefings.headline: Goldman Sachs Hires ex-Qatalyst Banker Brian Cayne to Co-lead Software
briefings.dek: The bank is gearing up for what it anticipates to be an “extremely active” year in software dealmaking.
briefings.body:
Goldman Sachs announced today it hired Brian Cayne as a partner and co-head of software investment banking.

Cayne co-founded Qatalyst Partners and spent more than 15 years at the technology-focused boutique bank. He most recently led its software practice and advised on deals including Zendesk’s $10 billion sale to Permira and Hellman & Friedman, Mailchimp’s $12 billion sale to Intuit and CA Technologies’s $18 billion sale to Broadcom.

Cayne, who took a break after 2023, said in an interview that he’s excited to return to investment banking at Goldman at a time where artificial intelligence is reshaping global industries. He’ll be based in San Francisco and work alongside existing co-heads Joe Porter in London and Jason Rowe in New York.

The bank is gearing up for what it anticipates to be an “extremely active” period that could top 2021, a year where tech M&A and IPO volume both hit record-highs, according to Porter.

The three Goldman bankers believe traditional software firms and private equity investors are grappling with AI, presenting opportunities for advisory work. There’s also a new crop of highly-valued AI startups that could step up as buyers of software companies.

“Suddenly you’ve got some new players on the field, which have massive capital availability and are all looking to figure out what part of the value chain they can play in,” said Rowe.

Goldman Sachs has led rivals in global software dealmaking and advised more than $990 billion worth of deals since 2022, more than half of total software mergers by volume, according to Dealogic. In 2025, the bank advised on Chronosphere’s $3.35 billion sale to Palo Alto Networks, Electronic Art’s $55 billion take-private by an investor consortium and cybersecurity startup Wiz’s $32 billion sale to Google.

related_items.title: Software’s Existential AI Crisis Is Bonanza for Bankers
Dealmakers Are Toasting a Solid Year for Tech M&A

briefings.headline: Polymarket Trader Made 1,242% Return on Venezuela Bet
briefings.dek: Bets related to U.S. actions on Venezuela are trending on Polymarket.
briefings.body:
An account on prediction market Polymarket drew attention on social media for correctly building up a position betting Venezuela’s President Nicolás Maduro would be out, making a return of 1,242% in just four days.

The account, created in December 2025, spent a total of $32,537 over the past four days betting that Maduro would be out by Jan. 31. As President Donald Trump confirmed the U.S. had captured Maduro early Saturday morning, the account made profits of $404,222, or a 1,242% return. It’s unclear who’s behind the account, or if the person has other accounts or positions. The account is also currently betting that the U.S. will invade Venezuela and Trump will invoke War Powers against Venezuela by the end of this month.

The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which regulates prediction markets in the U.S., generally forbids contracts related to events such as war, terrorism and assassination, which are contrary to the public interest. Polymarket’s global platform, where the account made its bets, is not open to U.S. users and therefore not subject to U.S. regulations. Polymarket has launched a separate platform for U.S. users.

Kalshi also offers bets on when Maduro would be leaving office, though there’s currently no bet on potential U.S. invasion of Venezuela.

briefings.headline: xAI Adds Grok Business Options as it Tries to Win Enterprise Customers
briefings.dek: The announcement is part of xAI’s effort to build an enterprise business to compete with the likes of Anthropic and OpenAI.
briefings.body:
xAI has introduced two new subscription tiers of its Grok artificial intelligence chatbot aimed at business customers. The announcement is part of xAI’s effort to build an enterprise business to compete with the likes of Anthropic and OpenAI.

The new offerings include Grok for Business, which is aimed at small-to-medium-sized businesses and costs $30 per user per month, and Grok Enterprise, which does not have publicly posted pricing and is aimed at larger companies. Both versions of Grok work with tools like Google Drive and have secure logins and billing designed for companies, xAI said. The enterprise version has extra features such as additional audit and security tools.

xAI faces an uphill battle winning over enterprise customers because it doesn’t have a large sales team and has a limited record selling to companies, though it has some small deals with companies such as Morgan Stanley and Palantir, The Information has reported. Musk’s own companies have also become enterprise customers for Grok, including by adding the chatbot to Tesla vehicles and using it for Starlink customer service at SpaceX.

related_items.title: Why xAI Has an Uphill Battle Selling Grok to Businesses

briefings.headline: xAI’s Grok Posts Sexualized Images of Minors on X
briefings.dek: X staff previously raised concerns that people could use Grok to generate sexualized images of real people, The Information has reported.
briefings.body:
xAI’s artificial intelligence chatbot Grok posted a series of sexualized images of minors on X over the past several days in response to prompts from users, a move the Grok account later attributed to “lapses in safeguards.”

In response to critical posts, the Grok account on X wrote Friday that it was “urgently fixing” its safeguards. It also deleted some of the images, which included images of minors that were modified to put them in revealing clothing. That would violate xAI’s terms of service, which forbid “the sexualization or exploitation of children” and “depicting likenesses of persons in a pornographic manner.”

xAI acquired X in March and has been integrating more AI features into the service, including letting X users tag the Grok account and make requests, as well introducing the ability to generate images using Grok within the X app. Some trust and safety staff at X have raised concerns about the way Grok has been integrated into the service, including the potential that people could use the tool to generate sexualized images of real people without their consent, The Information has reported.

related_items.title: The Twins Pushing Elon Musk’s Plans to Replace X Staff With Grok

briefings.headline: Tesla Deliveries Fell 16% in Fourth Quarter, Worsening 2025 Decline
briefings.dek: It was a worse-than-expected finish to the company’s second full year of falling sales.
briefings.body:
Tesla delivered 16% fewer vehicles in the fourth quarter of 2025 than it did during the same period during the previous year, a worse-than-expected finish to the company’s second full year of falling sales.

The Elon Musk-led automaker delivered 418,000 vehicles in the October-to-December quarter compared to 472,000 one year earlier. That was even lower than the analyst consensus estimate of about 423,000 that Tesla had flagged earlier this week, an apparent effort to lower expectations. The quarter was expected to show a drop, thanks to the September 30 expiration of a U.S. federal tax credit for electric vehicles.

But Tesla’s full year sales were down significantly, reflecting both the maturing of the electric vehicle market and the impact of Elon Musk’s political activities on Tesla’s sales. Tesla delivered a total of 1.64 million vehicles in 2025, down 9% from 1.79 million in 2024. The company’s best-ever year for sales was 2023, when it delivered 1.81 million vehicles. Tesla shares closed down nearly 3% on Friday.

Notably, the sales decline has been worse for Tesla’s newer and pricier models like the Cybertruck and Model S. Deliveries of “other models,” a category that excludes the popular Model 3 and Model Y vehicles, were down 51% year-over-year for the fourth quarter and 40% for the entire year.

briefings.headline: Baidu’s AI Chip Unit Files for Hong Kong Listing
briefings.dek: Baidu's move to spin off and list its chip business comes amid a wave of successful IPOs by Chinese AI chip companies.
briefings.body:
Chinese search giant Baidu said it AI chip subsidiary has filed confidentially for a Hong Kong listing. Baidu’s move to spin off the chip business and list it separately comes amid a wave of successful initial public offerings by Chinese AI chip companies.

Kunlunxin (Beijing) Technology, Baidu’s non-wholly owned chip subsidiary, will “leverage its standalone listing to enhance its market profile, broaden financial channels, and better align management accountability with performance,” Baidu said in a statement. Baidu’s stock is listed in New York and Hong Kong.

Baidu and Kunlunxin are betting on public market investors’ strong interest in China’s domestic semiconductor developers. The Chinese government is promoting the use of homegrown AI chips, as the country steps up its effort to reduce its dependence on U.S. chip giant Nvidia.

On Friday, Biren Technology, Chinese AI chip firm Shanghai Biren Technology’s stock surged on its debut on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Biren’s stock opened 82% higher than its IPO price, after the firm raised 5.85 billion Hong Kong dollars ($717 million) in its IPO. Last month, Moore Threads, another Chinese AI chip developer, also made a strong trading debut on Shanghai’s STAR market.

briefings.headline: Chinese AI Chip Firm Biren Soars on Hong Kong Stock Market Debut
briefings.dek: Chinese AI chip developers like Biren are expected to play key roles in Beijing’s effort to reduce the country’s dependence on Nvidia.
briefings.body:
Shares of Chinese AI chip developer Shanghai Biren Technology surged on their debut on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange Friday after the firm’s successful initial public offering.

The stock’s rise is the latest indication of investors’ strong interest in China’s domestic semiconductor sector.

On Friday, Biren’s stock opened 82% higher than its IPO price of 19.90 Hong Kong dollars. Biren’s IPO raised 5.85 billion Hong Kong dollars ($717 million).

The company’s strong trading debut comes at a time when the Chinese government is stepping up its effort to reduce the country’s dependence on Nvidia by promoting the use of homegrown AI chips developed by domestic companies. While tech giant Huawei Technologies is the largest domestic supplier of AI chips, Biren is one of several upstart competitors in China that also develop such chips.
